text: we have a system called design for
delight and customer driven innovation
and the approach is to really get into
the minds of our customers and
understand
what are the most important problems
that they have because
you can only build great solutions if
you really understand what the problem
is
and not just like what it is that you
want to build but why it's actually
important
and so we use this uh the system called
design for delight
where we do a lot of customer interviews
you work with a customer experience
researcher
and you know you just kind of see how
your customers are using your products
where are they getting stuck right what
is confusing for them
where are the tasks that you know
they're spending a lot of time on that
they wish they
were not doing and then there's also the
other piece which is
what if they wish that you actually had
that would make their lives a lot easier
and these are things that you know like
so there are some traditional methods
where you can infer it
by looking how a customer uses the
product but honestly it's just faster
to talk to a wide variety of customers
and have them tell you directly
so starting from that base where you
really understand what the problem is
that then we take it back and we say
okay what are some of the hypotheses
that we have
in creating the solution and the
solution could be
done by data science it could be done
via an experienced design
it could be done by some very simple
rules right
but what is the solution that you want
to build to solve that problem and then
you go into the mode of
decomposing it into okay like there's
the experience piece
there's the machine learning piece
there's the engineering piece
then we go off uh with these hypotheses
you know build a couple of quick
mvps uh minimum viable products
for our listeners who are new once we
have these mvps
the thing that i learned which actually
took me a little bit to appreciate
is that you know when you build an mvp
for a customer and you show it to them
you're like tell me how you would use
this would this be beneficial to you
in the past we would put in mock data
and then
you know the customer would say yeah you
know if this was my data
i would react this way i i would see
this
and it was actually not useful at all
because you're asking them to imagine
what they would do
and so we pivoted and moving forward
from about
three or four years ago when we found
this insight we actually just loaded the
customer's data
in we ran it through our models we made
the predictions
uh whatever and then we showed it to the
customer
and then immediately like the feedback
that we got back was so much richer
it actually helped us like narrow in on
the right solution
and it was just like you know this like
aha moment for me that i
i guess it's obvious now but was not
obvious back then
